results.title: The Ladykillers
results.creator_credit: Alexander Mackendrick, Sir Michael Balcon, Michael Balcon Productions and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
A black comedy from the Ealing Studios which features Alec Guinness and Peter Sellers. An innocent little old lady who takes in a sinister lodger finds out that he and four friends have committed a robbery. Once they realise she knows everything, they plot to kill her. However, just because she is the archetypal genteel old lady pensioner, doesn’t mean that she is quite as harmless as she seems. Also stars Jack Warner, Katie Johnson and Frankie Howerd.

results.title: Celebrations: new baby
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 6-8 outlining the ways people celebrate the addition of a new baby into their lives. Sharing the thoughts of a young boy who meets his new sister for the first time, and then later as they bring the baby home. The way people of different cultures celebrate the birth of a baby are also show, including a Catholic christening and a Vietnamese feast. Each family celebrates the birth in a different way, but all share the same purpose: to welcome a baby into their lives.

results.title: Family recreation
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard, Artransa Park Studios and Shell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fit to Live”.
Australians in most walks of life now have more leisure time at their disposal. There are many enjoyable, interesting and healthy ways of utilising this leisure time, and this film gives many suggestions - and much food for thought.

results.title: The Titfield Thunderbolt
results.creator_credit: Charles Crichton, Michael Truman, Michael Balcon Productions and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
When an antiquated railway line is threatened with closure, the villagers decide to run it themselves, entering into frenzied competition with the local bus route. Stanley Holloway as Mr Valentine, the village soak, becomes the railway benefactor and sets the wheels in motion. The antics of this eccentric rural community will provide a comic treat, while train lovers will appreciate the quest to save an old steam engine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles Crichton, Michael Truman, Michael Balcon Productions and Ealing Studios

results.title: Weather: wind
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video for children explains the mysteries of the wind from a child’s point of view - being scared of the wind at night. It tells of the importance of wind for sailing, gliding, balloonists and the use of the winds currents by birds in flight. There are wind storms, wind breaks, named winds, and the usefulness of wind which can carry seeds and clouds. The video ends with the statement of wind, “it can be heard, felt but not seen”.

results.title: Celebrations: New Year
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
Narrated by Eileen Darley, this program aimed at younger children looks at the celebrations surrounding New Year. It explores why people gather on December 31st and outlines characteristics of the event such as the countdown, singing Auld Lang Syne, and making resolutions. As a point of comparison the program then looks at how people in the Jewish tradition celebrate new year, and the celebrations surrounding Chinese New Year, revealing that food plays a major role in both. Suitable for children 4-8.

results.title: The Cruel sea
results.creator_credit: Charles Frend, Leslie Norman and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
A powerful moving documentary-style account of life on board a British warship during World War II. It is the courageous story of the battle of the Atlantic, a story of ocean, a shipand a handful of men. The only villain is the sea, that man and war have made even more brutal. Based on the novel by Nicholas Monsarrat and stars Jack Hawkins, Donald Sinden, Denholm Elliot and Virginia McKenna.

results.title: Celebrations: weddings
results.creator_credit: Keryn James and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 6-8 outlining the ways different cultures celebrate weddings. From a traditional Christian wedding to a Greek Orthodox ceremony, a Hindu service to a non-denominational ceremony, the roles of brides, grooms, and the differences in ceremony styles is discussed.

results.title: Weather: dry
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video explains the dry weather and its characteristics. It explains humidity and the effects dry weather has on farms and nature. The video talks of drought and how animals can adapt to periods of dry weather and also the effects of water wastage and conservation. Koalas and camels feature.

results.title: School for scoundrels
results.creator_credit: Robert Hamer, Hal E. Chester, Guardsman Film Productions and ABP
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
Amusing British comedy about a constant “loser” (Ian Carmichael) who enrols in Alistair Sim’s School of Lifemanship” and there learns all the tricks to allow him to win the girl and get the better of two unscrupulous used car salesmen (Dennis Price and Peter Jones) as well as his rival in love and on the tennis court, Terry Thomas. Based on the book by Stephen Potter.
